MP Andrew Bridgen has lost his job chairing the House of Commons Regulatory Reform Committee. 
The Tory North West Leicestershire MP has been replaced in the £15,025 role by fellow Conservative Stephen McPartland. Andrew Bridgen. 
Mr Bridgen headed the committee for 18 months during the last parliament but it has not met again since the election in June. Read More 
He told the Mercury he had expected to be re-elected as chair when the committee resumed on Tuesday. 
He said: “I thought it was a formality but there was a vote and I lost. 
“That is democracy. It is not the end of the world. 
“Being chair of a committee gives you a certain position but it is one of those things. 
Mr Bridgen, a prominent Brexit campaigner and outspoken Conservative backbencher, lost by nine votes to three. 
He said Labour members of the committee ‘had done a job on’ him. 
“They all turned up and Tory members didn’t," he said. 
“Being hated by the Labour party is not something that really bothers me. North West Leicestershire MP Andrew Bridgen 
“That committee will do nothing now. It will be paralysed.” 
Stevenage MP Mr McPartland said: “It’s an incredible privilege to be elected Chairman of this important committee. 
"I’d like to pay tribute to my predecessor Andrew Bridgen who made such an invaluable contribution in the last Parliament. 
"I look forward to working with the new Committee and staff.” Read More 
Mr Bridgen remains a a member of the 14 strong committee. Seven of it members are Tories, Labour has six representatives and there is on Scottish Nationalist Party. 
The committee drafts Legislative Reform Orders (LROs) which are a specific type of secondary legislation. 
An LRO is a statutory instrument laid before Parliament under the Legislative and Regulatory Reform Act 2006. Like us on Facebook
